table.name: Base Timing Idle Vehicle Speed Threshold
table.description: This value determines the vehicle speed threshold involved in determining the switch between multiple 'Base Timing Idle' tables.

table.name: Base Timing Idle Minimum
table.description: This is the minimum base timing in idle mode when vehicle speed is greater than the 'Base Timing Idle Minimum Vehicle Speed Enable' threshold.

table.name: Base Timing Idle Minimum Vehicle Speed Enable
table.description: The 'Base Timing Idle Minimum' table is active when vehicle speed is greater than this value.

table.name: Base Timing Alternate (ECT)
table.description: The timing indicated in this table is used as base timing when the target for this table exceeds the normal base timing target after compensations.

table.name: Knock Correction Advance Max
table.description: This is the maximum amount of knock-based timing advance (knock correction advance) that can be added to base timing. Total timing = base timing + knock correction advance + other timing compensations. Knock correction advance = (KC advance max map value * IAM) + feedback knock correction + fine learning knock correction.

table.name: Knock Correction Advance Max A
table.description: This is the maximum amount of knock-based timing advance (knock correction advance) that can be added to base timing. Total timing = base timing + knock correction advance + other timing compensations. Knock correction advance = (KC advance max map value * IAM) + feedback knock correction + fine learning knock correction.

table.name: Knock Correction Advance Max B
table.description: This is the maximum amount of knock-based timing advance (knock correction advance) that can be added to base timing. Total timing = base timing + knock correction advance + other timing compensations. Knock correction advance = (KC advance max map value * IAM) + feedback knock correction + fine learning knock correction.

table.name: Knock Correction Advance Max Additive (Knock Conditions)

scaling.units: Maximum Knock Correction Timing Advance Additive (degrees)

table.description: This is the maximum additive applied to knock correction primary advance. The actual additive applied depends on a number of factors, including knock, knock history and conditions that may support knock (note: this is not the same as IAM/FLKC/FBKC logic). This additive advance muliplier can range from 0 to 1. The multiplier determines which portion (if any) of additive advance is applied up to the max values in this table.

table.name: Knock Correction Advance Max Additive A (Knock Conditions)(IAM)

scaling.units: Maximum Knock Correction Timing Advance Additive (degrees)

table.description: This is the maximum additive A applied to knock correction primary advance. The actual additive A applied depends on a number of factors, including knock, knock history and conditions that may support knock (note: this is not the same as IAM/FLKC/FBKC logic). This additive advance A muliplier can range from 0 to 1. The multiplier determines which portion (if any) of additive advance A is applied up to the max values in this table. In addition, the IAM is applied to this value.

table.name: Knock Correction Advance Max Additive B (Knock Conditions)

scaling.units: Maximum Knock Correction Timing Advance Additive (degrees)

table.description: This is the maximum additive B applied to knock correction primary advance. The actual additive B applied depends on a number of factors, including knock, knock history and conditions that may support knock (note: this is not the same as IAM/FLKC/FBKC logic). This additive advance B muliplier can range from 0 to 1. The multiplier determines which portion (if any) of additive advance B is applied up to the max values in this table.

table.name: Knock Correction Advance Max Primary (Knock Conditions High)(IAM)
table.description: This is the maximum amount of knock-based timing advance (knock correction advance) that can be added to base timing when knock conditions are high. Knock conditions are determined based on a number of factors, including knock, knock history and conditions that may support knock (note: this is not the same as IAM/FLKC/FBKC logic). This primary advance multiplier, which ranges from 0 to 1, determines whether the low or high map is used (or a portion of each). Total timing = base timing + knock correction advance + other timing compensations. Knock correction advance = (((KCA max primary low * primary advance multiplier) + (KCA max primary high * (1.0 - primary advance multiplier))) * IAM) + KCA max additive.

table.name: Knock Correction Advance Max Primary (Knock Conditions Low)(IAM)
table.description: This is the maximum amount of knock-based timing advance (knock correction advance) that can be added to base timing when knock conditions are low. Knock conditions are determined based on a number of factors, including knock, knock history and conditions that may support knock (note: this is not the same as IAM/FLKC/FBKC logic). This primary advance multiplier, which ranges from 0 to 1, determines whether the low or high map is used (or a portion of each). Total timing = base timing + knock correction advance + other timing compensations. Knock correction advance = (((KC advance max primary low * primary advance multiplier) + (KC advance max primary high * (1.0 - primary advance multiplier))) * IAM) + KCA max additive.

table.name: Knock Correction Advance Max Primary Cruise (IAM)
table.description: This is the maximum amount of knock-based timing advance (knock correction advance) during cruise conditions that can be added to base timing. Cruise and non-cruise conditions are determined by a number of factors including engine speed, requested torque, MAF, vehicle speed, IAT, idle mode, ECT, and SI-Drive mode (if applicable). The ECU will ramp between the cruise and non-cruise map values when conditions dictate the switch. Total timing = base timing + knock correction advance + other timing compensations. Knock correction advance = ((KC advance primary max map value + KC advance final additive A) * IAM) + KC advance final additive B + feedback knock correction + fine learning knock correction.

table.name: Knock Correction Advance Max Cruise
table.description: This is the maximum amount of knock-based timing advance (knock correction advance) during cruise conditions that can be added to base timing. Cruise and non-cruise conditions are determined by a number of factors including engine speed, requested torque, MAF, vehicle speed, IAT, idle mode, ECT, and SI-Drive mode (if applicable). The ECU will ramp between the cruise and non-cruise map values when conditions dictate the switch. Total timing = base timing + knock correction advance + other timing compensations. Knock correction advance = (knock correction advance map value * IAM) + feedback knock correction + fine learning knock correction.

table.name: Knock Correction Advance Max Primary Non-Cruise (IAM)
table.description: This is the maximum amount of knock-based timing advance (knock correction advance) during cruise conditions that can be added to base timing. Cruise and non-cruise conditions are determined by a number of factors including engine speed, requested torque, MAF, vehicle speed, IAT, idle mode, ECT, and SI-Drive mode (if applicable). The ECU will ramp between the cruise and non-cruise map values when conditions dictate the switch. Total timing = base timing + knock correction advance + other timing compensations. Knock correction advance = ((KC advance primary max map value + KC advance final additive A) * IAM) + KC advance final additive B + feedback knock correction + fine learning knock correction.

table.name: Knock Correction Advance Max Non-Cruise
table.description: This is the maximum amount of knock-based timing advance (knock correction advance) during non-cruise conditions that can be added to base timing. Cruise and non-cruise conditions are determined by a number of factors including engine speed, requested torque, MAF, vehicle speed, IAT, idle mode, ECT, and SI-Drive mode (if applicable). The ECU will ramp between the cruise and non-cruise map values when conditions dictate the switch. Total timing = base timing + knock correction advance + other timing compensations. Knock correction advance = (knock correction advance map value * IAM) + feedback knock correction + fine learning knock correction.

table.name: Knock Correction Advance Alternate Mode
table.description: WARNING - DO NOT ENABLE ON COMMERCIALLY MODIFIED ROMS. When enabled, the alternate mode prevents the 'Knock Correction Advance Max Additive A (Knock Conditions)(IAM)' and 'Knock Correction Advance Max Additive B (Knock Conditions)' tables from impacting advance. In addition, this results in the ECU using only the individual alternate versions of the following tables - 'Target Boost (KCA Alternate Mode)', 'Initial Wastegate Duty (KCA Alternate Mode)', 'Primary Open Loop Fueling (KCA Alternate Mode)', and 'Primary Open Loop Fueling (Failsafe)(KCA Alternate Mode)'.

table.name: Knock Correction Advance Alternate Mode
table.description: WARNING - DO NOT ENABLE ON COMMERCIALLY MODIFIED ROMS. When enabled, the alternate mode prevents the 'Knock Correction Advance Max Additive (Knock Conditions)' table from impacting advance. In addition, this results in the ECU using the 'Map Ratio (Alternate)' multiplier to determine the map ratio switching for the following tables - 'Target Boost (KCA Additve Low)/(KCA Additve High)', 'Initial Wastegate Duty (KCA Additve Low)/(KCA Additve High)', 'Primary Open Loop Fueling (KCA Additve Low)/(KCA Additve High)', 'Primary Open Loop Fueling (Failsafe)(KCA Additve Low)/(KCA Additve High)', and 'Knock Correction Advance Max Primary (Knock Conditions Low)(IAM)/(Knock Conditions High)(IAM)'.

table.name: Knock Correction Advance Alternate Mode
table.description: WARNING - DO NOT ENABLE ON COMMERCIALLY MODIFIED ROMS. When enabled, the alternate mode prevents the 'Knock Correction Advance Max Additive A (Knock Conditions)(IAM)' and 'Knock Correction Advance Max Additive B (Knock Conditions)' tables from impacting advance. In addition, this results in the ECU using only the individual alternate versions of the following tables - 'Primary Open Loop Fueling (KCA Alternate Mode)', and 'Primary Open Loop Fueling (Failsafe)(KCA Alternate Mode)'.

table.name: Knock Correction Advance Additive Range (RPM)
table.description: This is the RPM range in which the knock correction advance additive multipliers could potentially be manipulated, possibly resulting in a change in the applied advance additive(s) as well as, partially, to the primary knock correction advance (which influences the map switching/ratio). When RPM is in the disable range, no change will be made to the current multipliers impacting knock correction additive advance and no change to some of the multipliers that determine primary knock correction advance.

table.name: Timing Compensation (IAT)
table.description: This is the change in total ignition timing based on intake temperature.

table.name: Timing Compensation A (IAT)
table.description: This is the change in total ignition timing based on input from the air intake temperature sensor.

table.name: Timing Compensation (IAT) Activation

scaling.units: Timing Compensation Intake Temp Map Target Compensation (%)

table.description: This is the compensation of the 'Timing Compensation (IAT)' target according to engine speed and load.

table.name: Timing Compensation (IAT) Activation

scaling.units: Timing Compensation Intake Temp Map Target Compensation (%)

table.description: This is the compensation of the 'Timing Compensation (IAT)' target according to engine speed and load.

table.name: Timing Compensation A (IAT) Activation

scaling.units: Timing Compensation Intake Temp Map Target Compensation (%)

table.description: This is the compensation of the 'Timing Compensation A (IAT)' target according to engine speed and load.

table.name: Timing Comp Min Load (IAT)
table.description: The minimum load necessary in order for the 'Timing Compensation (IAT)' table to be active.

table.name: Timing Compensation B (IAT)
table.description: This is the change in total ignition timing based on intake temperature when the knock signal is clear, the IAM is greater than the 'Timing Compensation B (IAT) IAM Activation' threshold, conditions are present where the knock sensor would be most accurate, and other factors. If a knock event occurs when this timing compensation is active, the ECU will ramp the compensation back to zero. Note: Even if this table has no compensation, compensation may still be added if the IAM is less than 1.0 and greater than the IAM activation threshold (see 'Timing Compensation B (IAT) Max Additive').

table.name: Timing Compensation B (IAT) IAM Activation
table.description: When the ignition advance multiplier (IAM) is greater than this threshold, the 'Timing Compensation B (IAT)' will potentially be active (dependent on other factors - see table help text). When the IAM is less than or equal to this threshold, this timing compensation will be set to zero.

table.name: Timing Compensation B (IAT) Max Additive

table.data: Max KCA Based Additive to 'Timing Compensation B (IAT)'

table.description: This value determines the max compensation that can be added to the current 'Timing Compensation B (IAT)' value. The ECU determines the potential additive as Knock Correction Advance Map Value - (Knock Correction Advance Map Value * IAM). This table's value limits this max additive.

table.name: Timing Compensation (ECT)
table.description: This is the change in total ignition timing based on coolant temperature.

table.name: Timing Compensation A (ECT)
table.description: This is the change in total ignition timing based on coolant temperature.

table.name: Timing Compensation B (ECT)
table.description: This is the change in total ignition timing based on coolant temperature.

table.name: Timing Compensation C (ECT)
table.description: This is the change in total ignition timing based on coolant temperature.

table.name: Timing Compensation D (ECT)
table.description: This is the change in total ignition timing based on coolant temperature.

table.name: Timing Compensation Imm. Cruise A (ECT)
table.description: This is the change in total ignition timing based on coolant temperature. Cruise and non-cruise conditions are determined by a number of factors including engine speed, requested torque, MAF, vehicle speed, IAT, idle mode, ECT, and SI-Drive mode (if applicable). Note: This is based on the immediate conditions related to cruise/non-cruise and results in an immediate switch, not the ramping behavior inherent with other tables when switching.

table.description: This is the change in total ignition timing based on manifold relative pressure and atmospheric pressure.

table.name: Timing Compensation Per Cylinder A
table.description: This is the change in total ignition timing per cylinder based on RPM. It is not currently known which table corresponds to which cylinder, however it is suspected that table A corresponds to cylinder #1. When logging 'ignition timing' only cylinder A is monitored.

table.name: Timing Comp Minimum Load (Per Cylinder)
table.description: The minimum load necessary in order for the 'Timing Compensation Per Cylinder' tables to be active. Active per cylinder compensation is also dependent on the 'Timing Comp Maximum RPM (Per Cylinder)' and 'Timing Comp Minimum Coolant Temp (Per Cylinder)' tables.

table.name: Timing Comp Maximum RPM (Per Cylinder)
table.description: This is the maximum engine speed for which the 'Timing Compensation Per Cylinder' tables are active. Active per cylinder compensation is also dependent on the 'Timing Comp Minimum Load (Per Cylinder)' and 'Timing Comp Minimum Coolant Temp (Per Cylinder)' tables.

table.name: Timing Comp Minimum Coolant Temp (Per Cylinder)
table.description: The minimum coolant temp necessary in order for the 'Timing Compensation Per Cylinder' tables to be active. Active per cylinder compensation is also dependent on the 'Timing Comp Maximum RPM (Per Cylinder)' and 'Timing Comp Minimum Engine Load (Per Cylinder)' tables.

table.name: Timing Compensation Per Gear (1st)
table.description: This is the change in total ignition timing in 1st gear based on RPM and engine load.

table.name: Timing Compensation Per Gear (2nd)
table.description: This is the change in total ignition timing in 2nd gear based on RPM and engine load.

table.name: Timing Compensation Per Gear (3rd)
table.description: This is the change in total ignition timing in 3rd gear based on RPM and engine load.

table.name: Timing Compensation Per Gear (4th)
table.description: This is the change in total ignition timing in 4th gear based on RPM and engine load.

table.name: Timing Compensation Per Gear (5th)
table.description: This is the change in total ignition timing in 5th gear based on RPM and engine load.

table.name: Timing Compensation Per Gear Activation (RPM)
Timing Compensation Per Gear Activation RPM

table.description: This is per-gear timing compensation activation threshold by RPM.

table.name: Timing Compensation Per Gear Activation (Load)
Timing Compensation Per Gear Activation Load

table.description: This is per-gear timing compensation activation threshold by load (g/rev).

table.name: Feedback Correction Range (RPM)
table.description: This is the engine speed range in which feedback corrections can be made by the ECU. Feedback correction is the immediate negative correction to timing advance due to knock as determined by the knock sensor.

table.name: Feedback Correction Minimum Load
table.description: This is the minimum engine load where feedback correction can be made by the ECU. Feedback correction is the immediate negative correction to advance due to knock as determined by the knock sensor.

table.name: Feedback Correction Minimum Load
table.description: This is the minimum engine load where feedback correction can be made by the ECU. Feedback correction is the immediate negative correction to advance due to knock as determined by the knock sensor.

table.name: Feedback Correction Retard Value

table.data: Potential Change in Current Feedback Correction Per Knock 'Event'

table.description: The step value for each negative adjustment to current feedback correction.

table.name: Feedback Correction Retard Value

scaling.units: Potential Change in Current Feedback Correction per Knock 'Event' (degrees of correction)

table.description: The step value for each negative adjustment to current feedback correction.

table.name: Feedback Correction Retard Limit
table.description: The limit for feedback correction.

table.name: Feedback Correction Negative Advance Value

table.data: Change in Negative Feedback Correction After Each 'No Knock' Delay

table.description: When feedback correction is negative and the knock signal is then clear, feedback correction does not immediately reset to zero. Instead, the negative correction is increased by the value in this table for each time period that passes with no knock as determined by the 'Feedback Correction Negative Advance Delay' table. Feedback correction will never be greater than zero.

table.name: Feedback Correction Negative Advance Delay

table.data: 'No Knock' Delay Period for Negative Feedback Correction Advance

table.description: When feedback correction is negative, this is the delay period over which if the knock signal is clear, the negative feedback correction will be incremented by the value in the 'Feedback Correction Negative Advance Value' table. This process will continue as long as the knock signal remains clear and the delay periods are satisfied until feedback correction is zero.

table.name: Feedback Correction Negative Advance Delay

scaling.units: 'No Knock' Delay Period for Negative Feedback Correction Advance (counter threshold)

table.description: When feedback correction is negative, this is the delay period over which if the knock signal is clear, the negative feedback correction will be incremented by the value in the 'Feedback Correction Negative Advance Value' table. This process will continue as long as the knock signal remains clear and the delay periods are satisfied until feedback correction is zero.

table.name: Extended Feedback Correction High RPM Compensation

table.data: Feedback Correction High RPM Carry-Over Compensation

table.description: If current feedback correction is non-zero as engine speed passes the last value in the 'Feedback Correction Range (RPM)' table, that feedback correction value continues to be applied even though engine speed is above the feedback correction disable RPM. The multiplier in this table determines the portion of that value that is applied. When engine speed drops back below the enable range, normal feedback correction activity will resume.

table.name: Fine Correction Range (RPM)
Potential Fine Correction Stored Value Adjustments

table.description: This is the engine speed range in which changes to the fine learning knock correction table in RAM can be potentially made by the ECU. Changes are based on knock or the relative lack of knock as determined by the knock sensor. In addition, other requirements must be met before changes can be made.

table.name: Fine Correction Minimum (RPM)
Potential Fine Correction Stored Value Adjustments

table.description: This is the engine speed range in which changes to the fine learning knock correction table in RAM can be potentially made by the ECU. Changes are based on knock or the relative lack of knock as determined by the knock sensor. In addition, other requirements must be met before changes can be made.

table.name: Fine Correction Maximum (RPM)
Potential Fine Correction Stored Value Adjustments

table.description: This is the engine speed range in which changes to the fine learning knock correction table in RAM can be potentially made by the ECU. Changes are based on knock or the relative lack of knock as determined by the knock sensor. In addition, other requirements must be met before changes can be made.

table.name: Fine Correction Range (Load)
Potential Fine Correction Stored Value Adjustments

table.description: This is the load range in which changes to the fine learning knock correction table in RAM can be potentially made by the ECU. Changes are based on knock or the relative lack of knock as determined by the knock sensor. In addition, other requirements must be met before changes can be made.

table.name: Fine Correction Rows (RPM)
table.description: These are the engine speed ranges that make up the fine learning correction table stored in RAM. These rpm ranges, as well as the load ranges specified by the 'Fine Correction Columns (Load)' table, determine how each fine correction value is stored as well as applied.

table.name: Fine Correction Rows (RPM)
table.description: These are the engine speed ranges that make up the fine learning correction table stored in RAM. These rpm ranges, as well as the load ranges specified by the 'Fine Correction Columns (Load)' table, determine how each fine correction value is stored as well as applied.

table.name: Fine Correction Columns (Load)
table.description: These are the engine load ranges that make up the fine learning correction table stored in RAM. These load ranges, as well as the rpm ranges specified by the 'Fine Correction Rows (RPM)' table, determine how each fine correction value is stored as well as applied.

table.name: Fine Correction Columns (Load)
table.description: These are the engine load ranges that make up the fine learning correction table stored in RAM. These load ranges, as well as the rpm ranges specified by the 'Fine Correction Rows (RPM)' table, determine how each fine correction value is stored as well as applied.

table.name: Fine Correction Retard Value

table.data: Potential Change in Fine Correction Stored Value Per Knock 'Event'

table.description: The step value for each individual negative adjustment to the fine correction learning table in RAM.

table.name: Fine Correction Retard Value A

table.data: Potential Change in Fine Correction Stored Value Per Knock 'Event'

table.description: The step value for each individual negative adjustment to the fine correction learning table in RAM.

table.name: Fine Correction Retard Value B

table.data: Potential Change in Fine Correction Stored Value Per Knock 'Event'

table.description: The step value for each individual negative adjustment to the fine correction learning table in RAM.

table.name: Fine Correction Retard Value

scaling.units: Potential Change in Fine Correction Stored Value Per Knock 'Event' (degrees of correction)

table.description: The step value for each individual negative adjustment to the fine correction learning table in RAM.

table.name: Fine Correction Retard Limit

table.data: Fine Correction Stored Value Negative Limit

table.description: The limit for each negative fine correction learning stored value.

table.name: Fine Correction Advance Value

table.data: Potential Change in Fine Correction Stored Value After Each 'No Knock' Delay

table.description: The step value for each individual positive adjustment to the fine correction learning table.

table.name: Fine Correction Advance Limit

table.data: Fine Correction Stored Value Positive Limit

table.description: The limit for each positive fine correction learning stored value.

table.name: Fine Correction Advance Delay

table.data: 'No Knock' Delay Period for Positive Change to Fine Correction Stored Value

table.description: This is the required minimum period of time with no knock, as determined by the knock sensor, before a potential positive adjustment to the fine correction learning table can be made.

table.name: Rough Correction Range (RPM)
table.description: This is the engine speed range in which changes to the ignition advance multiplier (IAM) can potentially be made by the ecu. When this and other specific requirements are met, the IAM is decreased when knock is encountered, as determined by the knock sensor, or the IAM is increased with the lack of knock over a specific period of time as determined by the 'Rough Correction Learning Delay (Increasing)' table. The enable range in the 'Rough Correction Range (Load)' table must also be satisfied for potential rough correction learning.

table.name: Rough Correction Range (Load)
table.description: This is the engine load range in which changes to the ignition advance multiplier (IAM) can potentially be made by the ecu. When this and other specific requirements are met, the IAM is decreased when knock is encountered, as determined by the knock sensor, or the IAM is increased with the lack of knock over a specific period of time as determined by the 'Rough Correction Learning Delay (Increasing)' table. The enable range in the 'Rough Correction Range (RPM)' table must also be satisfied for potential rough correction learning.

table.name: Rough Correction Minimum KC Advance Map Value

scaling.units: Current 'Knock Correction Advance Max' Map Value (degrees)

table.description: This is the minimum knock correction advance max map value in order to begin re-evaluation of the IAM after entering rough correction mode. This is one of several requirements that must be met.

table.name: Rough Correction Learning Delay (Increasing)

scaling.units: Rough Correction (IAM) Positive Learning Delay (counter threshold)

table.description: This is the required minimum period of time with no knock, as determined by the knock sensor, before a potential positive adjustment to the ignition advance multiplier (IAM) can be made when the IAM is being re-evaluated.

table.name: Rough Correction Learning Delay (Increasing)

scaling.units: Rough Correction (IAM) Positive Learning Delay (counter threshold)

table.description: This is the required minimum period of time with no knock, as determined by the knock sensor, before a potential positive adjustment to the ignition advance multiplier (IAM) can be made when the IAM is being re-evaluated.

table.name: Advance Multiplier (Initial)

table.data: Post-Reset or Active Rough Correction Initial Reset Value

table.description: This is the initial value for the ignition advance multiplier (IAM). The IAM is set to this value after an ECU reset and at the beginning of a rough correction learning session where the IAM would be re-evaluated.

table.name: Advance Multiplier Step Value

table.data: Initial IAM Step Value for Active Rough Correction

table.description: This is the initial change in the ignition advance multiplier (IAM) when re-evaluation of the IAM begins during a rough correction learning session. When this starts, the IAM is reset to the 'Advance Multiplier (Initial)' value and the step value is added to or subtracted from this value depending on knock. The step value is reduced by half when, during this session, the IAM changes from increasing to decreasing, or vice versa. When the step value is 0, or the IAM hits 0 or 1.0 for a period of time, the IAM re-evaluation ends. This how the ECU determines that the IAM has settled on the appropriate value.

table.description: This map selects the degree of intake cam advance for the variable valve timing system.

table.name: Requested Torque (Accelerator Pedal)
table.description: This table determines the driver requested torque based on the accelerator pedal angle and engine speed. This value is used to determine the target throttle plate angle as determined by the 'Target Throttle Plate Position (Requested Torque)' table.

table.name: Requested Torque A (Accelerator Pedal)
table.description: This table determines the driver requested torque based on the accelerator pedal angle and engine speed. This value is used to determine the target throttle plate angle as determined by the 'Target Throttle Plate Position (Requested Torque)' table.

table.name: Requested Torque B (Accelerator Pedal)
table.description: This table determines the driver requested torque based on the accelerator pedal angle and engine speed. This value is used to determine the target throttle plate angle as determined by the 'Target Throttle Plate Position (Requested Torque)' table.

table.name: Requested Torque C (Accelerator Pedal)
table.description: This table determines the driver requested torque based on the accelerator pedal angle and engine speed. This value is used to determine the target throttle plate angle as determined by the 'Target Throttle Plate Position (Requested Torque)' table.

table.name: Requested Torque D (Accelerator Pedal)
table.description: This table determines the driver requested torque based on the accelerator pedal angle and engine speed. This value is used to determine the target throttle plate angle as determined by the 'Target Throttle Plate Position (Requested Torque)' table.

table.name: Requested Torque E (Accelerator Pedal)
table.description: This table determines the driver requested torque based on the accelerator pedal angle and engine speed. This value is used to determine the target throttle plate angle as determined by the 'Target Throttle Plate Position (Requested Torque)' table.

table.description: This table determines the driver requested torque based on the accelerator pedal angle and engine speed. This value is used to determine the target throttle plate angle as determined by the 'Target Throttle Plate Position (Requested Torque)' table.

table.name: Requested Torque (Accelerator Pedal) SI-DRIVE Sport
table.description: This table determines the driver requested torque based on the accelerator pedal angle and engine speed when SI-DRIVE Sport mode is active. This value is used to determine the target throttle plate angle as determined by the 'Target Throttle Plate Position (Requested Torque)' table.

table.name: Requested Torque A (Accelerator Pedal) SI-DRIVE Sport
table.description: This table determines the driver requested torque based on the accelerator pedal angle and engine speed when SI-DRIVE Sport mode is active. This value is used to determine the target throttle plate angle as determined by the 'Target Throttle Plate Position (Requested Torque)' table.

table.name: Requested Torque B (Accelerator Pedal) SI-DRIVE Sport
table.description: This table determines the driver requested torque based on the accelerator pedal angle and engine speed when SI-DRIVE Sport mode is active. This value is used to determine the target throttle plate angle as determined by the 'Target Throttle Plate Position (Requested Torque)' table.

table.description: This table determines the driver requested torque based on the accelerator pedal angle and engine speed when SI-DRIVE Sport Sharp mode is active. table.name: Requested Torque (Accelerator Pedal) SI-DRIVE Intelligent
table.description: This table determines the driver requested torque based on the accelerator pedal angle and engine speed when SI-DRIVE Intelligent mode is active. table.name: Requested Torque A (Accelerator Pedal) SI-DRIVE Intelligent
table.description: This table determines the driver requested torque based on the accelerator pedal angle and engine speed when SI-DRIVE Intelligent mode is active. table.name: Requested Torque B (Accelerator Pedal) SI-DRIVE Intelligent
table.description: This table determines the driver requested torque based on the accelerator pedal angle and engine speed when SI-DRIVE Intelligent mode is active. This value is used to determine the target throttle plate angle as determined by the 'Target Throttle Plate Position (Requested Torque)' table.

table.name: Requested Torque Base (RPM)
table.description: The value determined by the 'Requested Torque (Accelerator Pedal)' table is divided by this table's value to determine the 'Requested Torque Accelerator Pedal to Requested Torque Base RPM' ratio. This ratio makes up the x-axis of the 'Target Throttle Plate Position (Requested Torque Ratio)' table.

table.name: Requested Torque Base (RPM)
table.description: The value determined by the 'Requested Torque (Accelerator Pedal)' table is divided by this table's value to determine the 'Requested Torque Accelerator Pedal to Requested Torque Base RPM' ratio. This ratio makes up the x-axis of the 'Target Throttle Plate Position (Requested Torque Ratio)' table.

table.name: Target Throttle Plate Position Cruise (Requested Torque Ratio)
table.description: This is the target throttle plate position during cruise conditions. Cruise and non-cruise conditions are determined by a number of factors including engine speed, requested torque, MAF, vehicle speed, IAT, idle mode, ECT, and SI-Drive mode (if applicable). The ECU will ramp between the cruise and non-cruise map values when conditions dictate the switch. The 'Requested Torque Accelerator Pedal to Requested Torque Base RPM (ratio)', which makes up the x-axis of this table, is the ratio of requested torque determined by the 'Requested Torque (Accelerator Pedal)' to the requested torque determined by the 'Requested Torque Base (RPM)' table. This ratio and engine speed are used to determine the target throttle plate opening.

table.name: Target Throttle Plate Position Non-Cruise (Requested Torque Ratio)
table.description: This is the target throttle plate position during non-cruise conditions. Cruise and non-cruise conditions are determined by a number of factors including engine speed, requested torque, MAF, vehicle speed, IAT, idle mode, ECT, and SI-Drive mode (if applicable). The ECU will ramp between the cruise and non-cruise map values when conditions dictate the switch. The 'Requested Torque Accelerator Pedal to Requested Torque Base RPM (ratio)', which makes up the x-axis of this table, is the ratio of requested torque determined by the 'Requested Torque (Accelerator Pedal)' to the requested torque determined by the 'Requested Torque Base (RPM)' table. This ratio and engine speed are used to determine the target throttle plate opening.

table.name: Target Throttle Plate Position Maximum (Requested Torque Ratio)
table.description: The 'Requested Torque Accelerator Pedal to Requested Torque Base RPM (ratio)', which makes up the x-axis of this table, is the ratio of requested torque determined by the 'Requested Torque (Accelerator Pedal)' to the requested torque determined by the 'Requested Torque Base (RPM)' table. This ratio and engine speed are used to determine the maximum target throttle plate opening. This maximum target throttle plate opening is used to limit the final target throttle plate opening determined by the A/B (or cruise/non-cruise) tables.

table.name: Target Throttle Plate Position (Requested Torque)
table.description: The target from the 'Requested Torque (Accelerator Pedal)' table and engine speed are used to determine the target throttle plate opening.

table.name: Target Throttle Plate Position Cruise (Requested Torque)
table.description: This is the target throttle plate position during cruise conditions. Cruise and non-cruise conditions are determined by a number of factors including engine speed, requested torque, MAF, vehicle speed, IAT, idle mode, ECT, and SI-Drive mode (if applicable). The ECU will ramp between the cruise and non-cruise map values when conditions dictate the switch. The target from the 'Requested Torque (Accelerator Pedal)' table and engine speed are used to determine the target throttle plate opening.

table.name: Target Throttle Plate Position Non-Cruise (Requested Torque)
table.description: This is the target throttle plate position during non-cruise conditions. Cruise and non-cruise conditions are determined by a number of factors including engine speed, requested torque, MAF, vehicle speed, IAT, idle mode, ECT, and SI-Drive mode (if applicable). The ECU will ramp between the cruise and non-cruise map values when conditions dictate the switch. The target from the 'Requested Torque (Accelerator Pedal)' table and engine speed are used to determine the target throttle plate opening.

table.name: Target Throttle Plate Position Maximum (Requested Torque)
table.description: The target from the 'Requested Torque (Accelerator Pedal)' table and engine speed are used to determine the maximum limit target throttle plate opening. This maximum target throttle plate opening is used to limit the final target throttle plate opening determined by the A/B tables.

table.name: Requested Torque Limit A (Per Gear/Engine Speed)
table.description: This table determines the Max requested torque based on calculated Gear and engine speed.

table.name: Requested Torque Limit B (Per Gear/Engine Speed)
table.description: This table determines the Max requested torque based on calculated Gear and engine speed.

table.name: Rev Limit (Fuel Cut)
table.description: These are the engine speeds at which the rev limiter is engaged and disengaged. When engine speed is equal to or exceeds the 'On' value, fuel cut is active, after which, if engine speed drops below the 'Off' value, fueling is resumed.

table.name: Rev Limit A
table.description: These are the engine speeds at which the rev limiter is engaged and disengaged. When engine speed is equal to or exceeds the 'On' value, fuel cut is active, after which, if engine speed drops below the 'Off' value, fueling is resumed.

table.name: Rev Limit B
table.description: These are the engine speeds at which the rev limiter is engaged and disengaged. When engine speed is equal to or exceeds the 'On' value, fuel cut is active, after which, if engine speed drops below the 'Off' value, fueling is resumed.

table.name: Rev Limit Fuel Resume (Boost)
table.description: After the rev limiter is engaged and engine speed drops below the 'Off' RPM, fueling will not resume until manifold pressure drops below this table's value.

table.name: Rev Limit Fuel Resume (MP)
table.description: After the rev limiter is engaged and engine speed drops below the 'Off' RPM, fueling will not resume until manifold pressure drops below this table's value.

table.name: Speed Limiting Enable (Fuel Cut)
table.description: The speed limiter is engaged when vehicle speed is greater than this value.

table.name: Speed Limiting Disable (Fuel Cut)
table.description: The speed limiter is disengaged when vehicle speed is equal to or drops below this value after already engaging the limiter.

table.name: Speed Limiting (Throttle)
table.description: The vehicle speed at which throttle is reduced.

table.name: Speed Limiting (Fuel Cut)
table.description: The vehicle speeds at which the speed limiter is engaged or disengaged which varies by transmission type.

table.name: Speed Limiting (Throttle)

table.name: Fuel Temp Sensor Scaling
table.description: This is the scaling for the fuel temp sensor.

table.name: Intake Temp Sensor Scaling
table.description: This is the scaling of the intake temp sensor.

table.name: Coolant Temp Sensor Scaling
table.description: This is the scaling of the coolant temp sensor.

table.name: Atmospheric Pressure Sensor Scaling
table.description: This is the scaling for the atmospheric pressure sensor. The multiplier is applied to atmospheric pressure sensor voltage and the offset is added to the result. The atmospheric pressure sensor is located inside the ECU.

table.name: Fuel Pump Duty Cycle
table.description: The ECU will set the fuel pump duty cycle to 0%, 100%, or one of these two values.

table.name: Radiator Fan Modes (ECT)
table.description: These are thresholds based on coolant temp which, along with the mode specified by the vehicle speed threshold table, are involved in determining radiator fan control. Radiator fan modes for coolant temp range from 0 to 2. Current mode thresholds are dependent on whether the coolant temperature is increasing or decreasing. Generally, as the coolant temp mode is higher and the vehicle speed mode is lower, the more likely the radiator fan(s) will come on. Whether the A/C is on or not also impacts the fan control. Other undefined thresholds may also change the behavior of the system.

Other undefined thresholds may also change the behavior of the system.

table.name: Gear Determination Thresholds
table.description: The ECU estimates the current gear based on rpm and vehicle speed and these are the thresholds for that determination. These should not be modified unless the transmission gear ratios have changed from the original factory set-up.

table.name: Ignition Dwell
table.description: UNVERIFIED - This table defines the amount of time before a spark event that the ECU needs to start charging the ignition system. Since the time needed to charge up the ignition doesn't change as engine speed increases, you need to start that event sooner to compensate for the piston moving faster.
